intro: Clarkia amoena subsp. caurina, commonly known as the Sierra clarkia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and streambanks. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and its flowers are arranged in clusters at the ends of the stems. This subspecies is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance in supporting pollinators.
